awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Eric D'Hoker, Michael Gutperle, and Per Kraus at the University of California, Los Angeles. 

String theory remains the most promising candidate for the unification of the Standard Model of elementary particles with General Relativity, the theory of gravitational forces, in a framework consistent with the laws of Quantum Mechanics.  Developments in string theory over the past decades have spawned progress in many areas of physics and mathematics, thereby serving the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical laws. Professors D'Hoker, Gutperle, and Kraus aim to deepen the understanding of string theory, quantum gravity, and black-hole physics by exploring new symmetry principles, new connections with pure mathematics, and by performing sophisticated calculations at the frontier of string theory. This project will also have significant broader impacts.  String theory continues to attract and inspire some of the brightest graduate students and postdocs in physics, and Professors D'Hoker, Gutperle, and Kraus will involve graduate students and postdocs in their research while actively mentoring them on their path to becoming professional scientists. Workshops organized with other universities in Southern California will serve to introduce junior physicists at UCLA to the broader community of researchers, while interactions with students during visits to local middle and high schools will promote public outreach. 

At a more technical level, Professor D'Hoker continues to advance the subject of superstring perturbation theory, its applications to the low-energy effective interactions of supergravity, and its implications for the high-energy behavior of string amplitudes. Professor Gutperle will investigate five-dimensional super-conformal field theories, as well as domain wall, surface, and line operators in conformal field theories utilizing the AdS/CFT correspondence.  Professor Kraus will study conformal field theories in various dimensions, with an emphasis on elucidating structures that have implications for quantum gravity via the AdS/CFT correspondence.  Professors D'Hoker, Gutperle, and Kraus will also use conformal-bootstrap methods to study the properties of the conformal field theory which is holographically dual to Type IIB string theory on AdS3.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of the projects funded by this grant was on string theory,
quantum gravity, holography and gauge-gravity duality, and
super-symmetric gauge theories at strong coupling.  The broader outcomes
of this project include mentoring graduate students and postdoctoral
researchers, collaborating with them on a number of vital parts of these
projects, and preparing them for career paths in academia and industry.

One outcome of this project concerns superstring amplitudes, evaluated
perturbatively at small string coupling in the loop expansion familiar
from quantum field theory. Specifically, the two-loop superstring
amplitudes with five external massless states were constructed
explicitly for the first time for all superstring theories. This result,
in turn, produced new predictions for the low energy effective
interactions that string theory produces in supergravity, thereby
offering novel insight into the space-time supersymmetry and strong
coupling duality properties of string theory. Another outcome concerns
the study of Yang-Mills theories with extended supersymmetry at strong
coupling, for which an improved expansion was developed near the
multi-monopole points. Through this expansion, a novel effective theory
was developed for soft supersymmetry breaking that predicts a cascade of
phase transitions from the pure Coulomb phase to the maximal Higgs phase.

Another project involved the construction and study of extended objects
such as line and surface defects as well as interfaces and boundaries in
quantum field theory. Quantum states built out of defects and boundaries
are ubiquitous in nature and provide new probes with which to study the
dynamics of the quantum theory. The method used here involves
holographic duality where quantum field theories are equivalent to
gravitational systems in higher dimensions. This duality allows for the
construction of novel defects and interfaces in quantum field theories
and the calculation of quantities such as the entropy of entanglement,
that are very difficult to calculate using other methods.

A further line of research involved the use of holographic duality to
study quantum gravity in a novel setting.  Quantum gravity is simplest
to study in spacetimes with infinite volume, since the dynamics
typically turns off in a far away region. However, physical laboratories
have finite volume, so one ultimately needs to formulate quantum gravity
within a finite region.   Progress was made on this problem by
considering the simplified setting of three spacetime dimensions, where
much of the dynamics localizes to the boundary.  It was shown how to
quantize this system and obtain the energy spectrum of excitations and
their interactions.  This setup is of further interest due to its
proposed holographic realization via a certain non-gravitational theory
in two spacetime dimensions, namely one deformed by the so-call TTbar
interaction, which involves the square of the energy density, along with
other terms.  This special interaction has certain soluble properties,
such as a known formula for the energy spectrum.   The coefficient of
the interaction has been conjectured to be related to the location of
the boundary in three-dimensional gravity description.   Research
carried out in this project established agreement between the energy
spectra of the gravitational and TTbar theories, in accord with the
conjectured relation, and enables further comparisons between other
physical quantities.
